titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Laurance S.) photographs, Photo Files, RG 1
A Guide to the Laurance S. Rockefeller photographs, Photo Files, RG 1 FA1128

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-21 14:13:35 -0400.

did.unittitle: Laurance S. Rockefeller photographs, Photo Files, RG 1

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (CDs) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Laurance Spelman Rockefeller was born on May 26, 1910, in New York City, the fourth of the six children of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. He attended Lincoln School, a progressive coeducational preparatory school connected with Teachers College of Columbia University in New York City, before entering Princeton in 1928. A philosophy major, he graduated from Princeton in 1932 with a B.A. degree in philosophy and went on to two years of graduate study at Harvard Law School.
On August 15, 1934, Laurance Rockefeller married Mary French in the Congregational Church in Woodstock, Vermont. Together they raised three daughters and a son.
During World War II, Laurance Rockefeller served in the Navy (1942-1945), attaining the rank of lieutenant commander.

Laurance Rockefeller pursued a number of successful careers during his lifetime. He was a pioneer in the field of venture capital. He was a leading and influential figure for three decades in the American conservation movement. He led the development of one of the world's foremost cancer care and research facilities, and was both a benefactor and advisor to major educational institutions. And, with great foresight, he combined his personal vision for conservation, recreation, and the spiritual needs of individuals to develop internationally acclaimed environmentally oriented resorts. His many accomplishments have been recognized both nationally and internationally.

In 1935, he began working in the family office in Rockefeller Center. His first duties were to develop his knowledge and understanding of Rockefeller philanthropic activities, conservation projects, and business interests, through both study and playing a modest role in their operation. Simultaneously, he developed his own special interest, blending business acumen with the talents of a "gadgeteer," a label he once pinned on himself.

He became well known as an investor of risk capital in young enterprises whose future was based primarily on scientific and technological developments. Over the years his investment interests included the fields of aviation, aerospace, electronics, high temperature physics, composite materials, optics, lasers, data processing, thermionics, instrumentation, and nuclear power. Beginning in August 1969, his venture capital investments in these areas were made through a venture capital group, Venrock, formed by members of the Rockefeller family.

In a different area of venture capital, he developed outstanding environmentally oriented resort hotels in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Hawaii, and Vermont, serving as chairman of Rockresorts, Inc., a resort management company which he founded and chaired.

Conservation of the environment and recreational development constituted much of Laurance Rockefeller's philanthropy and public service. His introduction to public service came in 1939 when Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York appointed him to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission (PIPC). He was president of the PIPC from 1970 to 1977 and continued as a commissioner until his resignation in December 1978. He was an advisor to Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, and Ford on matters of environmental conservation and outdoor recreation, and he worked on federal commissions set up to help develop national conservation and environmental policies and programs. In 1958, President Dwight D. Eisenhower appointed him chairman of the Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission (ORRRC), which charted ways of meeting the nation's outdoor recreation needs through the year 2000. He was a special emissary for President Lyndon Johnson in the effort that led to creation of the National Redwoods Park in California, and he served as chairman of President Nixon's Citizens' Advisory Committee on Environmental Quality, successor to a similar group which he headed under President Johnson. He played a pivotal role in the creation and development of several national parks including Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, Virgin Islands National Park on the island of St. John, and Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park in Vermont.

He served as a leader of several important nonprofit and philanthropic organizations. He was president and later chairman of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1958-1980) and was a trustee of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation (1960-1982). His first association with Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City was in 1947; he also served as chairman (1960-1982), overseeing an expansion and modernization of its operations. He was a longtime trustee of the New York Zoological Society (1935-1986) and served as its president (1969-1971) and chairman (1971-1985).

Laurance Rockefeller received many honors for his efforts on behalf of the environment and cancer research and treatment. Among them are the Alfred P. Sloan, Jr. Memorial Award from the American Cancer Society (1969), the Medal of Freedom (1969), Commander (Honorary) of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (1971), the Woodrow Wilson Award from Princeton University (1991), the Congressional Gold Medal (1991), the Chairman's Award from the National Geographic Society (1995), the Theodore Roosevelt National Park Medal of Honor (1995), and the Lady Bird Johnson Conservation Award for Lifetime Achievement (1997). In 2003, he became the first person to be made an honorary citizen of the British Virgin Islands in recognition of his many contributions to the area. In December 1959 he received the National Institute of Social Sciences' Gold Medal for distinguished services to humanity, an award previously bestowed upon his grandfather and father. This was the first time in the Institute's history that three generations of a family had been so honored. The citation to Laurance Rockefeller proclaimed him as a "creative organizer of ventures into new fields of human endeavor for the growing aspirations of mankind; [and a] leader in the conservation of natural resources and in the development of the medical and social sciences for the welfare of the individual." In 1967, the National Institute awarded Gold Medals to all five Rockefeller brothers in recognition of their individual and collective services to humanity.
Laurance Rockefeller died on July 11, 2004, at his home in Manhattan.
Prepared by Rockefeller Family and Associates, June 1982, and 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: FA1128 (LSR Photographs, RG 1, Photo Files) contains the bulk of LSR's loose photographic prints from his home and his office, along with some albums and slides. RG 1 is a composite collection. It contains LSR's loose or "flat" photo files, but also materials that for various reasons were not included in the other collection components at the time the collection was organized. RG 1 encompasses personal and family photos, as well as photographic documentation of LSR's business and civic activities. The Rockefeller Family Office's Public Relations files on Laurance and Mary French Rockefeller have also been included as a series in RG 1. Similarly, the photographs and albums from the former Series 1009 Photos (LSR Family) are now interfiled with RG 1.

Within FA1128, materials are arranged into series according to subject and then by particular subject or subheading within these categories. The finding aid descriptions for FA1128 follow this subject arrangement without regard to format, but oversized materials are housed in a separately numbered series of boxes (labeled O 1 – O 145).

Photos sized between 5"x7" and 8"x10" were considered part of the "5000" series of photos, and they received a 4-digit identifying number (starting with 5000). We have included these 5000-series photo identification numbers in notes at the file level, but there is no general index to these numbers. In addition, other photos carry a "photo index number" (also noted in file-level notes), which refers to a reference file created as part of a LSR-biography project. The photo index files are found in FA1128D, RG 5, LSR Photo Reference Files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The LSR Photograph collection is sorted into several component groupings, loosely based on format, or storage location (home or office), or use (e.g., Photo Reference files), at the time his collection was arranged and catalogued. RG 1 (FA1128) contains LSR's loose or "flat" photo files, plus materials that were not included in other collection components at the time the collection was organized. RG 2 (FA1128A) contains LSR's Albums (up to the late-1980s); RG 3 (FA1128B) consists of LSR's Slide Books; RG 4 (FA1128C) contains LSR's Snapshot Files; and RG 5 (FA1128D) comprises LSR's Photo Reference Files.
In organizing his collection, LSR's photo curators employed a system of numerical categories to arrange the material according to subject:

These classifications generally carried throughout the collection, with some variations or elaboration. (Series 400 - Civic, for example, may include a broad range of subheadings covering Business, Education, Health and Hospitals, Federal Government, etc.)

Within FA1128, materials are arranged into series according to subject and then by particular subject or subheading within these categories. The subjects generally correspond to LSR's numerical schema (though some subcategories have been elevated to series), but for the most part the photos in RG 1 do not carry these numerical labels. Series are arranged in alphabetical order by subject name.

RG 1 is arranged into thirteen series: 1 – Art; 2 – Awards; 3 – Business; 4 – Civic; 5 – Houses; 6 – Individuals and Dignitaries; 7 – Religion and Spirituality; 8 – Resorts; 9 – Laurance S. Rockefeller and Family; 10 – Travel; 11 – Vessels; 12 – Woodstock; 13 – Public Relations.

Prints signed (on mat) "W. McC." Prints originally housed in sleeves numbered 1-10 (number 8 not in file).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signing of Rockefeller Center lease. LSR, Eddie Rickenbacker, Thomas F. Armstrong, prior to flight, June 5, 1940. Rickenbacker signing lease (photocopy only; location of original unknown). Rockefeller Center ceremonies opening Eastern Air Lines building: LSR speaking, DR, Fiorello LaGuardia, October 15, 1940; LSR in propeller shop; photos of Rickenbacker. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autographed and other photos of notable personnages, mainly from JDR Jr.'s or the Aldrich family's collection. Items from JDR Jr. often include notes, dated January 15, 1937, on the individual and JDR Jr.'s relation to him or her. Includes Rosa Bonheur; M. A. Hanna; Lord Leverhulme; Orville Platt; L. Emmett Holt; Dame Henrietta Barnett; William B. Allison, Joseph G. Cannon; John C. Spooner; Cardinal Mercier, William A. (Billy) Sunday. Includes printed photos of William Henry Welch and Pius IX.

did.physdesc: OVERSIZED box 11x14 - 16x20 black and white prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autographed and other photos of notable personnages, mainly from JDR Jr.'s or the Aldrich family's collection. Items from JDR Jr. often include notes, dated January 15, 1937, on the individual and JDR Jr.'s relation to him or her. Subjects include Alexander of Tunis; Theodore Roosevelt; Juliana of the Netherlands; Mei Lang Fang; Elise Strang L'Esperance; Lord Balfour; Simon Flexner; Thomas Edison; Andr‚ Honnorat; J. C. Donnell; Charles M. Schwab; J. Barton Hepburn; William T. Dewart; Harry P. Davison; Nelson W. Aldrich; Charles W. Fairbanks; Garret Hobart. Includes some printed photos.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted due to preservation concerns. (Album sleeves are brittle).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four albums of LSR's photo negatives. Trips to England and France; 1924 Western trip; Seal Harbor, Maine; Ormond Beach, Florida; Pocantico Hills and New York. Albums include captions and identifications. Images include family members, LSR's ponies, Lincoln School friends. Transcribed list of image identifications included in box. For prints of some of these images see LSR's albums in boxes O 89 and O 90; and RG 2, series 1, album 100-0 (box A 6). (We have not checked the negative images against specific albums).

did.physdesc: Black and white 4x5 negatives of album pages (14 items).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy negatives of captioned photos from LSR's Western Trip albums (images not checked against specific albums). Mainly views of Mesa Verde, Grand Canyon, Yellowstone. Includes negative of LSR's pony Nancy.

did.physdesc: OVERSIZED framed photo collage 24 x 30.5 x 1.25.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Framed collage of photos of LSR, his family, and activities, created for his 80th birthday. Imprinted on mat: Laurance S. Rockefeller, Happy 80th, With much love from the Cousins and the Fifth Generation.

did.physdesc: Ring-bound album (8x9x1.5) of 4x6 color prints. Digital Media: photo CDs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album with photo of LSR on his 94th birthday, along with photos of flower arrangements and gifts he received. Two cds of photo of LSR and cropped photo. One color photocopy of cropped photo of LSR.

did.physdesc: Digital: CD-rom.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

did.physdesc: Black and white 8x10 print

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.36. LSR and MFR at United Neighborhood Houses Award dinner, honoring the Rockefeller Family and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, June 2, 1975, Pierre Hotel, New York. Photo from Women's Wear Daily, June 5, 1975.

did.unittitle: Palisades Interstate Park Commission: Fort Lee Historic Park
did.physdesc: 8x10 black and white prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.37. LSR, as vice president of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, speaking at ceremonies at Fort Lee Bluff. Includes photo of Continental army reenactors. Includes PIPC press release, November 23, 1964, concerning the cermonies and plans to acquire the property as an historical site

did.physdesc: Black and white 8x10 print

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.39. LSR receiving Theodore Roosevelt Association Distinguished Service Medal, as NAR looks on. Presented by Lyman Tondel.

did.unittitle: Conservation Service Award (U.S. Department of the Interior)
did.physdesc: Black and white 8x10 print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.41. LSR receiving award plaque from Stewart Udall, secretary of the Interior, at White House Conference on Conservation, May 25, 1962. NPS photo. Photo inscribed "For Laurance - Who won it many times over! Stewart." Includes covering note from Udall.

did.physdesc: Black and white 8x10 prints. Multiple copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.42. LSR, as chairman, presenting ORRRC report Outdoor Recreation for America to President John F. Kennedy, January 31, 1962, at the White House. MFR and other ORRRC members. Includes two contact sheets. At least some photos by UPI. Multiple shots; some cropped prints.

scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.46. Photo of LSR standing outdoors in Jackson Hole, Wyoming (winding camera). No date or other explanation of Wings Club attribution.

scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.49. LSR and others in hard hats on construction site (for MSKCC). No dating or identification provided.

did.unittitle: MSKCC: Dedication of New Hospital Building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: PR photo no. 2.72. LSR speaking at podium, in large tent, at MSKCC Dedication of New Hospital, 1973 November 13-14. (File mislabeled as LSR speaking before Citizens Advisory Committee on Natural Beauty and Recreation, Joint Meeting with Society for a More Beautiful National Capital, February 16, 1967 (for which, see 2.26). Correspondence from file 2.72 moved to file 2.26.) Plus two shots moved to this file from file 2.49.
